dt: {bc}to respond to, challenge, or disparage the claim or opinion of (someone)
usually used in the phrase {phrase}don't @ me{/phrase}

dt.t: It goes without saying that Lucille Ball's comedic timing is unmatched—{wi}don't @ me{/wi}, you'll be wrong.
I'll cut right to the chase: Men should be able to wear makeup, {wi}don't at me{/wi}.

shortdef: to respond to, challenge, or disparage the claim or opinion of (someone) —usually used in the phrase don't @ me

meta.id: better the devil you know than the devil you don't
stems: better the devil you know than the devil you don't

hwi.hw: better the devil you know than the devil you don't

dt: used to say that it is better to deal with a difficult person or situation one knows than with a new person or situation that could be worse

shortdef: —used to say that it is better to deal with a difficult person or situation one knows than with a new person or situation that could be worse

dt: used to say that something is too strange, embarrassing, or complicated to explain

dt.t: "She married and divorced a man in the same day? How is that possible?" "{it}Don't ask{/it}."

shortdef: —used to say that something is too strange, embarrassing, or complicated to explain

dt: used to say that one does not know the answer to a question

dt.t: "Why are they having a company meeting?" "{it}Don't ask me{/it}. I only work here."
{it}Don't ask me{/it} why they're changing the system. I think it's fine the way it is.

shortdef: —used to say that one does not know the answer to a question

stems: don't even think about doing it

dt: used to tell someone in a forceful way that something is not allowed

dt.t: It's illegal to park here. {it}Don't even think about it{/it}!

shortdef: —used to tell someone in a forceful way that something is not allowed

dt: used in speech to show annoyance when someone tells one something that one does not believe or accept

dt.t: "It's not my fault that we're late." "Don't give me that! You were the one who said we didn't have to leave early!"

shortdef: —used in speech to show annoyance when someone tells one something that one does not believe or accept

dt: use to say that one does not know (something)

shortdef: —use to say that one does not know (something)

dt: used when someone is in a hurry and needs someone to move or act more quickly

dt.t: Hurry up! I {it}don't have all day{/it}!

shortdef: —used when someone is in a hurry and needs someone to move or act more quickly

dt: used to say that one agree with what has just been said

dt.t: "It's freezing in here!" "{it}Don't I know it{/it}."

shortdef: —used to say that one agree with what has just been said

dt: used to say that one wants something to happen but knows it will probably not happen

dt.t: "Did he ask you to the dance?" "{it}I wish{/it}!"
"Will you be getting the job?" "{it}Don't I wish{/it}!"

shortdef: —used to say that one wants something to happen but knows it will probably not happen
